title: What is the first known Christian religion? - Quora

response.answer_text: The New Testament calls the first Christians the followers of the Way. Here is what we know about them: They were Jews. They held with the Unitarian monotheism common to all Jews. (Acts 2:22)They lived in communes and shared everything from a community pool, practicing the ideal of every person according to their need (Acts 4:32)They practiced believer’s baptism (Acts 8:36-37)They accepted Gentile worshipers into the community under the conditions of what Jews call the Noahide Laws (Acts 15:19–21, Seven Laws of Noah - Wikipedia )They had a communal meal and teaching on the first day of the week (Acts 20:7)They encouraged members to be faithful to the Torah and practicing it (Romans 2:11–13)They believed in some idea of a purification place like Purgatory after death (1 Conrinthians 3:15)They kept the Passover (1 Corinthians 5:7–8)They took the commemoration of the Lord’s body and blood (Communion) as a serious thing (1 Corinthians 11:27)They practiced proxy baptism for the dead, but it is unknown under what conditions (1 Corinthians 15:29)They believed Jesus was returning soon, before all the first believers had passed away (1 Thessalonians 4:15–17)They believed in some concept of mortal sin (1 John 5:16)They later believed that Jesus wasn’t returning within the lifetime of first generation believers, but still soon (Revelation 22:20)

The first know Christian religion was called Jesus and his disciples. And it’s pretty much still the only real Christian religion today. In Acts 11, we read that “The disciples were first called Christians at Antioch.” So the name disciples even pre-dates the word “Christian”. These first Christians were also referred to as “the sect of the Nazarene”, and as “the people of the Way”. As another answer has pointed out, there was a prophesied falling away, or apostasy, that occurred when these same people were lured into compromise with the Roman Emperor, Constantine, and things have been a mess ever since.
